Authors:
Athina Kiourtsoglou, Antigoni Kaliontzopoulou, Dimitris
Poursanidis, Daniel Jablonski, Petros Lymberakis, Nikos Poulakakis
Title:
Evidence of cryptic diversity in Podarcis peloponnesiacus and
re-evaluation of its current taxonomy; insights from genetic,
morphological and ecological data
Journal:
Journal of Zoological Systematics and Evolutionary
Research
Keywords:
mitochondrial DNA, nuclear DNA, Phylogeny, Phylogeography,
southern Balkans, Species delimitation, Systematics
Abstract:
The Peloponnese wall-lizard, Podarcis peloponnesiacus, is
an endemic species to the area of Peloponnese. Although the phylogeny
and species diversity of the Balkan Podarcis have been extensively
studied, the intraspecific relationships of P. peloponnesiacus are not
yet well defined. The aim of this study was to investigate the
intraspecific diversity in this species and clarify its taxonomic status
by analysing eight gene fragments (two mitochondrial and six nuclear)
and several morphological traits, typically used for systematic
inferences within the genus Podarcis. Together with ecological niche
modelling we provided an integrative evaluation of the differentiation
between lineages. The combination of several phylogenetic, species
delimitation and chronophylogenetic analyses revealed the existence of
two highly supported and divergent clades with distinct geographic and
parapatric distribution and high niche overlap. The differentiation of
the two clades dates back to Pleistocene and is probably correlated with
the paleogeography of Peloponnese. These clades were also differed in
several phenotypic traits, which, however, exhibit extensive overlap and
are not fully diagnostic. The combination of the above results permits
us the identification of those clades as distinct species.
